G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 218, § 19**, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the statutory jurisdictional limit of the District Court and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

Newton City Ordinance \u00a7\u00a7 9-30.proposition: Defendant was present that day with his large dog, which he regularly allowed to run loose in the park without a leash, contrary to said posted regulations and in violation of **Newton City Ordinance §§ 9-30 and 9-33**, as well as **G.L. c. 140, § 173**, which require dog owners to restrain their animals in public places.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173.proposition: Defendant was present that day with his large dog, which he regularly allowed to run loose in the park without a leash, contrary to said posted regulations and in violation of **Newton City Ordinance §§ 9-30 and 9-33**, as well as **G.L. c. 140, § 173**, which require dog owners to restrain their animals in public places.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Under **Massachusetts common law**, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care so as not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. *See* **Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**; **Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000)**.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The court in Jupin explicitly states a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, citing prior authority and the Restatement. It then applies that duty analysis in detail to the specific facts of negligent firearm storage. This squarely supports the broad common-law duty proposition for which the case is cited.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Under **Massachusetts common law**, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care so as not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. *See* **Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006)**; **Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000)**.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Glidden v. Maglio discusses the elements of negligence (duty, breach, causation, damages) and disposes of the case on causation grounds. It does not articulate the broad Massachusetts common-law principle that every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid subjecting others to unreasonable risk of harm. The opinion even notes it need not decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care, focusing instead on plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation, so it does not serve as authority for the general duty proposition cited.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965)… Causation is an essential element of that proof.… [W]e need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.”

Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 1.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to control his dog and prevent foreseeable harm. *See* **Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 185 (1990)**; **Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47 (1983)**.
Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co. concerns a products liability and Chapter 93A claim arising from a defective printing press and failure to warn; it does not involve animals, dog ownership, or any duty to control a dog. The court’s analysis focuses on negligence, breach of implied warranty of merchantability, admissibility of evidence, and consumer protection, not on duties of landowners or dog owners to prevent foreseeable harm from dogs. Therefore it does not support the proposition that a defendant owed a plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to control his dog.
Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that “the defendant breached its warranty of merchantability in that it failed to warn of dangerous conditions. The machine in its condition was not of merchantable quality. As a result, [the] plaintiff’s hand became caught and crushed by the machine . . . .” The judge noted the jury’s answers to special questions, which indicated that the plaintiff was unaware “that the product was defective and dangerous . . . .” The judge also took notice of the jury’s conclusion that the defendant was negligent.

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to control his dog and prevent foreseeable harm. *See* **Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 185 (1990)**; **Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47 (1983)**.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This passage from Mullins concerns premises liability and proximate causation arising from a sexual assault in a college dormitory; it does not involve animals or any duty to control a dog. While Mullins (particularly the majority) discusses a landowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from foreseeable criminal acts, that is conceptually distinct from (and does not establish) a specific duty of reasonable care to control one’s dog. Citing Mullins for a dog-control duty stretches the case beyond its actual holding and subject matter.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Defendant’s failure to leash his dog constituted a breach of duty, violating both statutory and common-law standards of care. *See* **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)** (violation of a statute or ordinance may be evidence of negligence); **Guinan v. Famous Players–Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929)**.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion does say that violation of a statute or ordinance is only ‘some evidence’ of negligence and not negligence per se, but it does not involve dogs, leashes, or the specific duty alleged in the proposition. Bennett addresses statutory violations in the context of dram shop liability and emphasizes that such violations do not themselves establish breach of duty. Thus, while it is proper authority for the general evidentiary effect of statutory violations, it does not support the specific claim that failing to leash a dog constituted a breach of duty in this case.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. … Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.”

Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.raw_text: Guinan v. Famous Players–Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929)
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.proposition: Defendant’s failure to leash his dog constituted a breach of duty, violating both statutory and common-law standards of care. *See* **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)** (violation of a statute or ordinance may be evidence of negligence); **Guinan v. Famous Players–Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929)**.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.support_reasoning: Guinan involves negligence arising from the unsafe disposal of highly inflammable scrap motion picture film and the violation of a fire-prevention regulation; it does not concern dogs, leashes, or animal-control statutes. The case is cited there for the general rule that violation of a statute or regulation is evidence of negligence and for the duty to safely dispose of a dangerous substance, not for any duty to leash a dog. Thus, relying on Guinan for a dog‑leash duty mischaracterizes its holding and context.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2013Lasky Corp.relevant_excerpt: “The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent. Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. … Gordon v. Bedard, 265 Mass. 408, 411.”

Leibovich v. Antonellis, 410 Mass. 568 (.proposition: The risk that an unleashed dog could frighten pedestrians or joggers, causing injury, is both *foreseeable* and *natural*. *See* **Leibovich v. Antonellis, 410 Mass. 568 (1991)** (foreseeable risk analysis applies to negligence), and **Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)**.
Leibovich v. Antonellis, 410 Mass. 568 (.support_reasoning: This opinion is about negligence, but it does not involve dogs, pedestrians, joggers, or fright-based injuries, nor does it discuss the foreseeability or naturalness of such a risk. Leibovich focuses on expert qualification, tax instructions to the jury, and retroactive application of a filial consortium statute; its negligence discussion is limited to speed and causation in a motor vehicle collision. It therefore cannot be authority for the specific foreseeability proposition stated about unleashed dogs frightening pedestrians or joggers.
Leibovich v. Antonellis, 410 Mass. 568 (.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant’s liability was premised on the jury’s finding that he had been traveling well above the posted speed limit of twenty-five miles per hour at the time of the accident. There was ample testimony at trial as to the defendant’s speed. An eyewitness to the accident testified that she estimated that the defendant’s truck had been traveling between forty-five and fifty miles per hour prior to the collision.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The risk that an unleashed dog could frighten pedestrians or joggers, causing injury, is both *foreseeable* and *natural*. *See* **Leibovich v. Antonellis, 410 Mass. 568 (1991)** (foreseeable risk analysis applies to negligence), and **Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)**.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: Poskus v. Lombardo’s is a premises-liability / negligent-security case about an assault in a parking lot, not about dog-related injuries or whether dogs frightening pedestrians is a foreseeable and natural risk. The quoted concurring passage only discusses foreseeability in the context of whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk created by the defendant’s negligence in that case. It does not address, analogize to, or establish any rule concerning unleashed dogs or similar animal-fright scenarios, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Souza v. United States, 726 F.2d 49 (1st.raw_text: Souza v. United States, 726 F.2d 49 (1st Cir. 1984)
Souza v. United States, 726 F.2d 49 (1st.proposition: Plaintiff’s reaction to avoid a perceived threat was reasonable under the circumstances, satisfying the legal standard of proximate cause as articulated in **Restatement (Second) of Torts § 296**, adopted in **Souza v. United States, 726 F.2d 49 (1st Cir. 1984)** (applying Massachusetts law).
Souza v. United States, 726 F.2d 49 (1st.support_reasoning: The opinion reproduced is not Souza v. United States at all, but United States v. Luce, a federal criminal case about possession and transfer of an unregistered silencer. It does not mention Restatement (Second) of Torts § 296, proximate cause, or any tort standard assessing the reasonableness of a plaintiff’s reaction to a perceived threat. Because the case text addresses criminal firearms definitions and entrapment only, it provides no authority for the tort proximate-cause proposition claimed.
Souza v. United States, 726 F.2d 49 (1st.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion in this opinion of Restatement (Second) of Torts § 296, proximate cause, or the reasonableness of a plaintiff’s reaction to a perceived threat; the case concerns the definition of a silencer under 26 U.S.C. § 5845(a) and the defense of entrapment in a federal firearms prosecution.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, including physical pain, medical expenses, and loss of income. *See* **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010)**.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos concerns premises liability for slip‑and‑fall injuries on snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, but it does not decide that Target’s negligence directly and proximately caused Papadopoulos’s specific injuries or his resulting damages. The SJC merely vacates summary judgment and remands for application of a reasonable‑care standard; it does not make any findings on causation or on the plaintiff’s physical pain, medical expenses, or loss of income. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific causation-and-damages proposition cited.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Because we now abolish the distinction between the natural and unnatural accumulation of snow and ice, and because we apply the premises liability standard of reasonable care retroactively to injuries from slips and falls arising from accumulations of snow and ice, we vacate the allowance of summary judgment in favor of the defendants, and remand the case to the Superior Court for reconsideration of the defendants’ motion for summary judgment in light of this opinion.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor in bringing about the harm sustained. *See* **Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (2002)**.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses causation but holds that the defendant Commonwealth’s conduct was not the proximate (legal) cause of the harm; it does not stand for the proposition that the defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor in bringing about the harm. Indeed, the court finds the causal chain too remote and superseded by later acts, and ultimately orders dismissal of the negligence claims. Thus, citing Kent for the affirmative proposition that the defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor is inaccurate and contrary to the holding.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.relevant_excerpt: “Although deciding the issue of causation on a motion to dismiss may present the exception rather than the rule…there is no set of facts that the plaintiffs could prove to support a conclusion that the Commonwealth’s decision to parole MacNeil to the INS deportation warrant in 1987 was the proximate cause of Kent’s injuries in 1995. The Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the claims for negligence should have been allowed.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff **prejudgment interest** pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
